title: 106_s1627
content: The "NRC Fairness in Funding Act of 2000" includes provisions for Nuclear Regulatory Commission annual charges, authority over former licensees for decommissioning funding, and cost recovery from Government agencies. It also covers office location, license period, gift acceptance authority, carrying of firearms by licensee employees, and sabotage of nuclear facilities or fuel. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 is amended to change the deadline and adjust the aggregate amount of charges collected from licensees and certificate holders by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 amended the deadline and adjusted the charges collected by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission from licensees and certificate holders. Percentages for amounts collected and appropriated from the Nuclear Waste Fund were specified for fiscal years 2001 to 2005. SEC. 102 of the Atomic Energy Act is amended to ensure sufficient funds for decommissioning of licensed facilities. SEC. 103 addresses cost recovery from government agencies. SEC. 103 of the Atomic Energy Act is amended to allow the Commission to collect fees from government agencies starting October 1, 2000. SEC. 202 amends the Atomic Energy Act to specify the license period for combined construction and operating licenses. SEC. 203 eliminates NRC antitrust reviews. SEC. 203 eliminates NRC antitrust reviews for pending or new license applications for utilization facilities under the Atomic Energy Act. SEC. 204 grants gift acceptance authority. SEC. 204 grants the Nuclear Regulatory Commission the authority to accept gifts of real and personal property to aid its work. Criteria for accepting gifts are outlined in the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission establishes criteria for accepting gifts to ensure integrity. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 outlines these criteria. Additionally, licensee employees are allowed to carry firearms under SEC. 205. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to authorize certain individuals to carry firearms in the performance of official duties at facilities owned by or contracted to the United States. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to authorize designated individuals to carry firearms at facilities owned or operated by Commission licensees or certificate holders for the protection of property of significance to the common defense and security. SEC. 170D. CARRYING OF FIREARMS for protection of property at facilities owned or operated by Commission licensees or certificate holders. A person authorized to carry a firearm under section 161k can arrest an individual without a warrant for a federal offense committed in their presence or for a felony if there is reasonable belief. Contractors or employees authorized to make arrests can only do so within the area where the offense occurred. The text chunk discusses the enforcement of laws related to property of the United States, facilities owned by Commission licensees, and property significant to defense and security. The text chunk discusses the arrest authority granted under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 for offenses related to defense and security, in addition to other existing arrest authorities. Guidelines for implementation will be issued by the Secretary and the Commission with the approval of the Attorney General. Conforming and technical amendments will be made to the table of contents of chapter 14 of the Act. Chapter 14 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include new provisions related to arrest authority. SEC. 206. UNAUTHORIZED INTRODUCTION OF DANGEROUS WEAPONS. Section 229a of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include licensing authority of the Commission or certification by the Commission under this Act or any other Act. SEC. 207. SABOTAGE OF NUCLEAR FACILITIES OR FUEL. Section 236a of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include licensing for storage, treatment, or disposal facilities, utilization facilities licensed under the Act, nuclear fuel fabrication facilities, and various nuclear-related activities. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include licensing for storage, treatment, or disposal facilities, uranium enrichment, and nuclear fuel fabrication facilities, with a focus on public health and safety during facility operation. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's authority to collect fees is extended through 2005 by the passage of S. 1627 in the 106th Congress.
